values.description:
started py3 compat in response to issue #16

- `from __future__` and `future_builtins` added to all modules
- moved from `PKG` to `__package__` in `__init__.py`. I didn't enforce py2.7+ anywhere because there are a variety of ways to do that and I'm sure Michael has a favorite way.
- all `print` functions coverted to py3 style (using `2to3`)
- `2to3` also changed a variety of interface details (`iteritems` to `items`, `xrange` to `range` etc)
- switched from `optparse` to `argparse` throughout. more consistent use of `gdarchive` in modules.
- removed redundant `die` definitions and moved `die` into `_util.py`
- package wide `__version__` imports from `__init__.py` allows command line interface to report correct package version. removed CVS-style `__version__ = '$Revision$'` definitions from  modules.

Also:
- added `sizes` command to `genomedata-info`

All tests pass. BUT should really write a test cases that directly test the command line interfaces, maybe something like: http://dustinrcollins.com/testing-python-command-line-apps.
values.title: started py3 compatbility improvements

summary.raw:
started py3 compat in response to issue #16

- `from __future__` and `future_builtins` added to all modules
- moved from `PKG` to `__package__` in `__init__.py`. I didn't enforce py2.7+ anywhere because there are a variety of ways to do that and I'm sure Michael has a favorite way.
- all `print` functions coverted to py3 style (using `2to3`)
- `2to3` also changed a variety of interface details (`iteritems` to `items`, `xrange` to `range` etc)
- switched from `optparse` to `argparse` throughout. more consistent use of `gdarchive` in modules.
- removed redundant `die` definitions and moved `die` into `_util.py`
- package wide `__version__` imports from `__init__.py` allows command line interface to report correct package version. removed CVS-style `__version__ = '$Revision$'` definitions from  modules.

Also:
- added `sizes` command to `genomedata-info`

All tests pass. BUT should really write a test cases that directly test the command line interfaces, maybe something like: http://dustinrcollins.com/testing-python-command-line-apps.
summary.html:
started py3 compat in response to issue #16

  • from __future__ and future_builtins added to all modules
  • moved from PKG to __package__ in __init__.py. I didn't enforce py2.7+ anywhere because there are a variety of ways to do that and I'm sure Michael has a favorite way.
  • all print functions coverted to py3 style (using 2to3)
  • 2to3 also changed a variety of interface details (iteritems to items, xrange to range etc)
  • switched from optparse to argparse throughout. more consistent use of gdarchive in modules.
  • removed redundant die definitions and moved die into _util.py
  • package wide __version__ imports from __init__.py allows command line interface to report correct package version. removed CVS-style __version__ = '$Revision$' definitions from modules.

Also: - added sizes command to genomedata-info

All tests pass. BUT should really write a test cases that directly test the command line interfaces, maybe something like: http://dustinrcollins.com/testing-python-command-line-apps.

values.description:
This fixes a bug in the name of one of the arguments given from the python interface. It also accurately displays the usage of the python interface. 

Before, the interface specified that the genomedata archive could come after the tracknames but this was never possible.
values.title: Fix genomedata-open-data interface and usage specification

values.description: This pull request adds automatic loading of the BigWig file format if the UCSC tool "bigWigToBedGraph" utility is present on the system. The tests all currently pass and will skip on bigWig loading if the utility is not present.
values.title: Add support for automatic loading of the bigWig file format

summary.raw: This pull request adds automatic loading of the BigWig file format if the UCSC tool "bigWigToBedGraph" utility is present on the system. The tests all currently pass and will skip on bigWig loading if the utility is not present.
summary.html: This pull request adds automatic loading of the BigWig file format if the UCSC tool "bigWigToBedGraph" utility is present on the system. The tests all currently pass and will skip on bigWig loading if the utility is not present.

values.description:
For example,


```
#!python

genomedata-load -t /absolute/filepath/here/test1.bed -t test2.bedGraph ...

```
results in 


```
#!python

track name: test1 from track file: /absolute/filepath/here/test1.bed
track name: test2 from track file: test2.bedGraph

```

---

Also, please see issue 23 [here](#!/hoffmanlab/genomedata/issues/23/genomedata-load-does-not-throw-the-correct).

And lastly, another question is if we should raise a warning if any track names will be the same.
values.title: Infer track names from signal files

summary.raw:
For example,


```
#!python

genomedata-load -t /absolute/filepath/here/test1.bed -t test2.bedGraph ...

```
results in 


```
#!python

track name: test1 from track file: /absolute/filepath/here/test1.bed
track name: test2 from track file: test2.bedGraph

```

---

Also, please see issue 23 [here](#!/hoffmanlab/genomedata/issues/23/genomedata-load-does-not-throw-the-correct).

And lastly, another question is if we should raise a warning if any track names will be the same.
summary.html:
For example,

genomedata-load -t /absolute/filepath/here/test1.bed -t test2.bedGraph ...

results in 

track name: test1 from track file: /absolute/filepath/here/test1.bed
track name: test2 from track file: test2.bedGraph

Also, please see issue 23 here.

And lastly, another question is if we should raise a warning if any track names will be the same.

values.description:
Hi,

I created a test chr1.fa file matching the example [here](https://www.pmgenomics.ca/hoffmanlab/proj/genomedata/doc/1.3.6/genomedata.html#example). When I run the genomedata-load-seq command:

```
#!shell

genomedata-load-seq genomedata.test chr1.fa
```

I get the following error:

```
#!shell

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/bin/genomedata-load-seq", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 318, in main
    mode=args.mode, seqfile_type=args.seqfile_type)
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 250, in load_seq
    assert seqfile_type in frozenset(["agp", "fasta"])
AssertionError
```

Looking at the code, the problem seems to be that the argument seqfile_type gets set to None. Adding a default="fasta" option to the --assembly argument fixes the bug, but I admit I am not entirely sure why, since it should get set to that default by the --sizes argument.

Versions of things:

Python 2.7.3
numpy 1.11.0
pytables 3.3.0
hdf5 1.8.18
segway 1.4.1
values.title: Fix assertion failure on argument parsing when loading fasta sequence

```
#!shell

genomedata-load-seq genomedata.test chr1.fa
```

I get the following error:

```
#!shell

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/bin/genomedata-load-seq", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 318, in main
    mode=args.mode, seqfile_type=args.seqfile_type)
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 250, in load_seq
    assert seqfile_type in frozenset(["agp", "fasta"])
AssertionError
```

Looking at the code, the problem seems to be that the argument seqfile_type gets set to None. Adding a default="fasta" option to the --assembly argument fixes the bug, but I admit I am not entirely sure why, since it should get set to that default by the --sizes argument.

numpy 1.11.0

hdf5 1.8.18
segway 1.4.1
summary.html:
Hi,

I created a test chr1.fa file matching the example here. When I run the genomedata-load-seq command:

genomedata-load-seq genomedata.test chr1.fa

I get the following error:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/bin/genomedata-load-seq", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 318, in main
    mode=args.mode, seqfile_type=args.seqfile_type)
  File "/net/noble/vol2/home/katecook/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/genomedata/_load_seq.py", line 250, in load_seq
    assert seqfile_type in frozenset(["agp", "fasta"])
AssertionError

Looking at the code, the problem seems to be that the argument seqfile_type gets set to None. Adding a default="fasta" option to the --assembly argument fixes the bug, but I admit I am not entirely sure why, since it should get set to that default by the --sizes argument.

Versions of things:

Python 2.7.3 numpy 1.11.0 pytables 3.3.0 hdf5 1.8.18 segway 1.4.1

values.description:
This PR fixes Issue #22.

Previously genomedata-load woulld accidentally default to fasta files regardless if --assembly was specified or not. Changes here were made to not break the existing interface.

The docs were updated to clarify that the method used in Issue #22 (appending agp files) is not correct and that globbing is the better approach for now.
values.title: Fix genomedata-load to detect assembly AGP file and clarify docs on use

summary.raw:
This PR fixes Issue #22.

Previously genomedata-load woulld accidentally default to fasta files regardless if --assembly was specified or not. Changes here were made to not break the existing interface.

The docs were updated to clarify that the method used in Issue #22 (appending agp files) is not correct and that globbing is the better approach for now.
summary.html:
This PR fixes Issue #22.

Previously genomedata-load woulld accidentally default to fasta files regardless if --assembly was specified or not. Changes here were made to not break the existing interface.

The docs were updated to clarify that the method used in Issue #22 (appending agp files) is not correct and that globbing is the better approach for now.

* Remove erroneous AGP filename usage from docs

* Update NEWS

  • Update NEWS

values.description:
* Enable writing of non-track indexed data to genomedata archives

* Add support for writing based on track key and checking writes across supercontig boundaries

* Update NEWS on ability to write to archives

There is some concern about what the expected behavior is when writing across supercontigs. Currently if data written overlaps any region that isn't covered by a supercontig, an error is raised. This can be changed and might be a good subject of discussion.
values.title: Add feature to write data to archives

summary.raw:
* Enable writing of non-track indexed data to genomedata archives

* Add support for writing based on track key and checking writes across supercontig boundaries

* Update NEWS on ability to write to archives

There is some concern about what the expected behavior is when writing across supercontigs. Currently if data written overlaps any region that isn't covered by a supercontig, an error is raised. This can be changed and might be a good subject of discussion.
summary.html:
• Enable writing of non-track indexed data to genomedata archives

  • Add support for writing based on track key and checking writes across supercontig boundaries

  • Update NEWS on ability to write to archives

There is some concern about what the expected behavior is when writing across supercontigs. Currently if data written overlaps any region that isn't covered by a supercontig, an error is raised. This can be changed and might be a good subject of discussion.

values.description:
Replace tabdelim dependency with csv module.

Simple test:


```
#!bash

$ head hs_ref_GRCh38.p7_chr1.agp 
# Homo sapiens chromosome 1, GRCh38.p7 Primary Assembly
#
# This file provides assembly instructions for sequence NC_000001.11
# included in assembly GCF_000001405.33
##agp-version 2.0
# Format: object object_beg object_end part_number component_type component_id component_beg component_end  orientation
#   Gaps: object object_beg object_end part_number     N          gap_length   gap_type      linkage        evidence
chr1	1	10000	1	N	10000	telomere	no	na
chr1	10001	10615	2	F	AP006221.1	36117	36731	-
chr1	10616	177417	3	F	AL627309.15	103	166904	+
```


```
#!bash

$ genomedata-load --assembly -s hs_ref_GRCh38.p7_chr1.agp -t testtrack1=testtrack1.bedgraph GDARCHIVE
$ genomedata-report GDARCHIVE 
measurement testtrack1
mean    1.0
var 0.0
$ genomedata-info tracknames_continuous GDARCHIVE 
['testtrack1']

```

values.description:
Code changes in this pull request generally fall into one of the following categories:

* ArgumentParser no longer accepts a version argument as part of its constructor; it must be added as a separate parsed argument (modified for all genomedata tools)
* tracknames must be encoded into the hdf5 archive as bytestrings (resulting in a CSET_ASCII attribute), or else some unicode craziness will happen (this is very possibly related to a known numpy pickling issue, as pytables uses numpy pickling internally). 
* Python 3 is much less lax about type checking, so sometimes objects need to be checked for whether they're byte type or unicode type, and then encoded as appropriate.
* Generators in Py2 and Py3 have different structure (`next` in Py2 is now `__next__` in Py3)
* Installation changes, please see below.

Notes on installation changes:

* `build_scripts.run` in Python 3 now expects a script of Unicode encoding, but we are able to get around that by overriding the `detect_encoding` function in `tokenize` to pass a latin-1 encoding for our binary's case (which raises a `SyntaxError`):

```
#!python

      File "/scratch/software/lib/python3.6/tokenize.py", line 395, in find_cookie
        raise SyntaxError(msg)
    SyntaxError: invalid or missing encoding declaration for 'build/scripts-3.6/Linux_x86_64/genomedata-load-data'
```


The patch is taken from passacre ([ref](https://github.com/habnabit/passacre/commit/2ea05ba94eab2d26951ae7b4b51abf53132b20f0)). The `detect_encoding` function does not exist in Python 2's `tokenize` module, so it does not affect installation in Python 2. Installation using `pip` using this workaround works the same as usual.

* Notably, installing using `python setup.py install` is no longer supported due to issues with `easy_install` (Unicode issues and exception catching issues amongst other things). 

For example,

The `is_python` function in `setuptools.easy_install` expects a `TypeError` if null bytes (eg a binary) in Py2:


```
#!python

> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1879)is_python()
-> compile(text, filename, 'exec')
(Pdb) n
TypeError: 'compile() expected string without null bytes'
> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1879)is_python()
-> compile(text, filename, 'exec')
(Pdb) 
> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1880)is_python()
-> except (SyntaxError, TypeError):
```

which is why it worked before, but in Py3:


```
#!python

File "/scratch/software/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py", line 1862, in is_python
    compile(text, filename, 'exec')
ValueError: source code string cannot contain null bytes
```

a ValueError is given instead, hence why this no longer works. Technically, we can get around this by overriding the function in `easy_install` (and all the others that now break for various reasons), but after discussing with Eric, we decided we would simply not support `python setup.py install` in the future and instead support only pip.

Compatability notes:

* Python 3/2-created genomedata archives seem compatible with Python 2/3 genomedata operations using basic tests that I tried, though Python 2/3-created archives differ in encoding for some attributes and the null/0 dataspace for the hdf5 'title' attribute (historically left empty in genomedata archives). 
* It is possible that reverse-compatibility may break if the user uses, for example, Chinese characters in their tracknames etc.

For those with access to mordor, vimdiffs of the h5dumps can be found here:

* py2 genomedata archive modified by py3 genomedata, vimdiff of original py2 archive with modified-by-py3 archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py2to3diff.html))
* py3 genomedata archive modified by py2 genomedata, vimdiff of original py3 archive with modified-by-py2 archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py3to2diff.html))
* py2 genomedata archive compared with a py3 genomedata archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py2orig_py3orig_diff.html))
* modified-by-py3 py2 archive vs modified-by-py2 py3 archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py2to3_py3to2_diff.html))

Tests notes:

* Using the same code base, all tests pass using Py2 genomedata and Py3 genomedata, though note that Python 3 will spew out a billion ResourceWarnings (because we pass an open file handle around). There is not an easy way to disable this, as the `unittest` module resets the warning filters to default at every test. If this is an issue, I can try manually overriding it at every test--please let me know.
values.title: Genomedata python3 compatibility

summary.raw:
Code changes in this pull request generally fall into one of the following categories:

* ArgumentParser no longer accepts a version argument as part of its constructor; it must be added as a separate parsed argument (modified for all genomedata tools)
* tracknames must be encoded into the hdf5 archive as bytestrings (resulting in a CSET_ASCII attribute), or else some unicode craziness will happen (this is very possibly related to a known numpy pickling issue, as pytables uses numpy pickling internally). 
* Python 3 is much less lax about type checking, so sometimes objects need to be checked for whether they're byte type or unicode type, and then encoded as appropriate.
* Generators in Py2 and Py3 have different structure (`next` in Py2 is now `__next__` in Py3)
* Installation changes, please see below.

Notes on installation changes:

* `build_scripts.run` in Python 3 now expects a script of Unicode encoding, but we are able to get around that by overriding the `detect_encoding` function in `tokenize` to pass a latin-1 encoding for our binary's case (which raises a `SyntaxError`):

```
#!python

      File "/scratch/software/lib/python3.6/tokenize.py", line 395, in find_cookie
        raise SyntaxError(msg)
    SyntaxError: invalid or missing encoding declaration for 'build/scripts-3.6/Linux_x86_64/genomedata-load-data'
```


The patch is taken from passacre ([ref](https://github.com/habnabit/passacre/commit/2ea05ba94eab2d26951ae7b4b51abf53132b20f0)). The `detect_encoding` function does not exist in Python 2's `tokenize` module, so it does not affect installation in Python 2. Installation using `pip` using this workaround works the same as usual.

* Notably, installing using `python setup.py install` is no longer supported due to issues with `easy_install` (Unicode issues and exception catching issues amongst other things). 

For example,

The `is_python` function in `setuptools.easy_install` expects a `TypeError` if null bytes (eg a binary) in Py2:


```
#!python

> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1879)is_python()
-> compile(text, filename, 'exec')
(Pdb) n
TypeError: 'compile() expected string without null bytes'
> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1879)is_python()
-> compile(text, filename, 'exec')
(Pdb) 
> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1880)is_python()
-> except (SyntaxError, TypeError):
```

which is why it worked before, but in Py3:


```
#!python

File "/scratch/software/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py", line 1862, in is_python
    compile(text, filename, 'exec')
ValueError: source code string cannot contain null bytes
```

a ValueError is given instead, hence why this no longer works. Technically, we can get around this by overriding the function in `easy_install` (and all the others that now break for various reasons), but after discussing with Eric, we decided we would simply not support `python setup.py install` in the future and instead support only pip.

Compatability notes:

* Python 3/2-created genomedata archives seem compatible with Python 2/3 genomedata operations using basic tests that I tried, though Python 2/3-created archives differ in encoding for some attributes and the null/0 dataspace for the hdf5 'title' attribute (historically left empty in genomedata archives). 
* It is possible that reverse-compatibility may break if the user uses, for example, Chinese characters in their tracknames etc.

For those with access to mordor, vimdiffs of the h5dumps can be found here:

* py2 genomedata archive modified by py3 genomedata, vimdiff of original py2 archive with modified-by-py3 archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py2to3diff.html))
* py3 genomedata archive modified by py2 genomedata, vimdiff of original py3 archive with modified-by-py2 archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py3to2diff.html))
* py2 genomedata archive compared with a py3 genomedata archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py2orig_py3orig_diff.html))
* modified-by-py3 py2 archive vs modified-by-py2 py3 archive ([ref](http://mordor/hoffmanlab/people/rcwchan/internal/2017/data/20170719_py2to3_py3to2_diff.html))

Tests notes:

* Using the same code base, all tests pass using Py2 genomedata and Py3 genomedata, though note that Python 3 will spew out a billion ResourceWarnings (because we pass an open file handle around). There is not an easy way to disable this, as the `unittest` module resets the warning filters to default at every test. If this is an issue, I can try manually overriding it at every test--please let me know.
summary.html:
Code changes in this pull request generally fall into one of the following categories:

  • ArgumentParser no longer accepts a version argument as part of its constructor; it must be added as a separate parsed argument (modified for all genomedata tools)
  • tracknames must be encoded into the hdf5 archive as bytestrings (resulting in a CSET_ASCII attribute), or else some unicode craziness will happen (this is very possibly related to a known numpy pickling issue, as pytables uses numpy pickling internally).
  • Python 3 is much less lax about type checking, so sometimes objects need to be checked for whether they're byte type or unicode type, and then encoded as appropriate.
  • Generators in Py2 and Py3 have different structure (next in Py2 is now __next__ in Py3)
  • Installation changes, please see below.

Notes on installation changes:

  • build_scripts.run in Python 3 now expects a script of Unicode encoding, but we are able to get around that by overriding the detect_encoding function in tokenize to pass a latin-1 encoding for our binary's case (which raises a SyntaxError):
      File "/scratch/software/lib/python3.6/tokenize.py", line 395, in find_cookie
        raise SyntaxError(msg)
    SyntaxError: invalid or missing encoding declaration for 'build/scripts-3.6/Linux_x86_64/genomedata-load-data'

The patch is taken from passacre (ref). The detect_encoding function does not exist in Python 2's tokenize module, so it does not affect installation in Python 2. Installation using pip using this workaround works the same as usual.

  • Notably, installing using python setup.py install is no longer supported due to issues with easy_install (Unicode issues and exception catching issues amongst other things).

For example,

The is_python function in setuptools.easy_install expects a TypeError if null bytes (eg a binary) in Py2:

> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1879)is_python()
-> compile(text, filename, 'exec')
(Pdb) n
TypeError: 'compile() expected string without null bytes'
> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1879)is_python()
-> compile(text, filename, 'exec')
(Pdb) 
> /scratch/software/lib/python2.7/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py(1880)is_python()
-> except (SyntaxError, TypeError):

which is why it worked before, but in Py3:

File "/scratch/software/lib/python3.6/site-packages/setuptools/command/easy_install.py", line 1862, in is_python
    compile(text, filename, 'exec')
ValueError: source code string cannot contain null bytes

a ValueError is given instead, hence why this no longer works. Technically, we can get around this by overriding the function in easy_install (and all the others that now break for various reasons), but after discussing with Eric, we decided we would simply not support python setup.py install in the future and instead support only pip.

Compatability notes:

  • Python 3/2-created genomedata archives seem compatible with Python 2/3 genomedata operations using basic tests that I tried, though Python 2/3-created archives differ in encoding for some attributes and the null/0 dataspace for the hdf5 'title' attribute (historically left empty in genomedata archives).
  • It is possible that reverse-compatibility may break if the user uses, for example, Chinese characters in their tracknames etc.

For those with access to mordor, vimdiffs of the h5dumps can be found here:

  • py2 genomedata archive modified by py3 genomedata, vimdiff of original py2 archive with modified-by-py3 archive (ref)
  • py3 genomedata archive modified by py2 genomedata, vimdiff of original py3 archive with modified-by-py2 archive (ref)
  • py2 genomedata archive compared with a py3 genomedata archive (ref)
  • modified-by-py3 py2 archive vs modified-by-py2 py3 archive (ref)

Tests notes:

  • Using the same code base, all tests pass using Py2 genomedata and Py3 genomedata, though note that Python 3 will spew out a billion ResourceWarnings (because we pass an open file handle around). There is not an easy way to disable this, as the unittest module resets the warning filters to default at every test. If this is an issue, I can try manually overriding it at every test--please let me know.

values.description:
This PR adds the feature of providing a hard mask BED file to prevent regions from writing into the genomedata archive while loading in data.

* Add --hardmask option to genomedata-load
* Add maskfile argument to load_genomedata
* Add maskfile argument to load_data
* Update NEWS and documentation on masking option for genomedata-load
values.title: Hard mask genomedata load

summary.raw:
This PR adds the feature of providing a hard mask BED file to prevent regions from writing into the genomedata archive while loading in data.

* Add --hardmask option to genomedata-load
* Add maskfile argument to load_genomedata
* Add maskfile argument to load_data
* Update NEWS and documentation on masking option for genomedata-load
summary.html:
This PR adds the feature of providing a hard mask BED file to prevent regions from writing into the genomedata archive while loading in data.

  • Add --hardmask option to genomedata-load
  • Add maskfile argument to load_genomedata
  • Add maskfile argument to load_data
  • Update NEWS and documentation on masking option for genomedata-load

values.description:
Chunk metadata is now updated for telomeric regions where the chunk start/end boundaries do not start until data is first/last defined for a chromosome respectively.

Chunk metadata now takes into account gaps between supercontigs where there is no data present greater than `MIN_GAP_LEN`.

Empty supercontigs that form gaps greater than `MIN_GAP_LEN` of missing data before and after itself are considered empty and have empty chunk metadata.

Closes Issue #43
values.title: Better chunk metadata for gaps in telomeric regions and between supercontigs

summary.raw:
Chunk metadata is now updated for telomeric regions where the chunk start/end boundaries do not start until data is first/last defined for a chromosome respectively.

Chunk metadata now takes into account gaps between supercontigs where there is no data present greater than `MIN_GAP_LEN`.

Empty supercontigs that form gaps greater than `MIN_GAP_LEN` of missing data before and after itself are considered empty and have empty chunk metadata.

Closes Issue #43
summary.html:
Chunk metadata is now updated for telomeric regions where the chunk start/end boundaries do not start until data is first/last defined for a chromosome respectively.

Chunk metadata now takes into account gaps between supercontigs where there is no data present greater than MIN_GAP_LEN.

Empty supercontigs that form gaps greater than MIN_GAP_LEN of missing data before and after itself are considered empty and have empty chunk metadata.

Closes Issue #43

values.description:
This fix addresses a leak in `H5Gopen` and `H5Gclose` calls where in `get_cols`, `H5Gclose` seemed to be erroneously omitted.

From running the test suite this seems to fix segfault issues in later versions of HDF5 \(>= 1.10\) and will therefore be compatible with later versions of PyTables \(in conda\).
values.title: Fix HDF5 group leak in genomedata-load-data

summary.raw:
This fix addresses a leak in `H5Gopen` and `H5Gclose` calls where in `get_cols`, `H5Gclose` seemed to be erroneously omitted.

From running the test suite this seems to fix segfault issues in later versions of HDF5 \(>= 1.10\) and will therefore be compatible with later versions of PyTables \(in conda\).
summary.html:
This fix addresses a leak in H5Gopen and H5Gclose calls where in get_cols, H5Gclose seemed to be erroneously omitted.

From running the test suite this seems to fix segfault issues in later versions of HDF5 (>= 1.10) and will therefore be compatible with later versions of PyTables (in conda).

values.description: Created pipeline to test both python 2 and 3 simultaneously and updated program file to be compatible with both python 2 and 3. Only error currently present in the test cases is the seg fault which Eric has fixed.
values.title: Pipeline Update and Python 3 Compatibility

summary.raw: Created pipeline to test both python 2 and 3 simultaneously and updated program file to be compatible with both python 2 and 3. Only error currently present in the test cases is the seg fault which Eric has fixed.

values.description: This pull request addresses the issue of directly adjacent AGP entries being considered as separate contigs by merging all adjacent contigs.
values.title: Merge adjacent AGP entries when forming supercontigs

summary.raw: This pull request addresses the issue of directly adjacent AGP entries being considered as separate contigs by merging all adjacent contigs.
